summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence between U.S. Department of Justice officials in August 2021 regarding the drafting and submission of an MLAT (Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty) request to the United Kingdom concerning the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The emails discuss the content of the request, specifically debating whether to include a request for Jeffrey Epstein's and Maxwell's border crossing records due to concerns it might trigger scrutiny related to Prince Andrew and delay the process.

persons.name: Lara
persons.context: The primary correspondent from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS), drafting and revising the MLAT request for the Maxwell investigation.

persons.name: John T. McNeil
persons.role: U.S. Department of Justice Attaché - London
persons.context: The DOJ Attaché at the U.S. Embassy in London responsible for facilitating and submitting the MLAT request to the UK Central Authority (UKCA). He provides strategic advice on the request's content.

persons.name: Taylor Cole
persons.context: A DOJ official copied on the email chain, involved in the coordination of the MLAT request.

persons.name: Jennifer L. Schroeder-Fawcett
persons.role: Attaché, U.S. Customs and Border Protection
persons.context: The CBP Attaché in London who provides technical information about available travel record data fields (APIS) in response to an inquiry from John McNeil.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the criminal investigation (case 182-73090) for which the MLAT request is being prepared.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of a proposed request for his border crossing records as part of the Maxwell investigation.

persons.name: P. Andrew
persons.context: Referenced by John McNeil as a potential sensitivity; he worries UK authorities might think the border crossing request is aimed at gathering information on him, which could cause delay.

connections.description: Colleagues coordinating the submission of an MLAT request from the U.S. Attorney's Office to the UK authorities for the Maxwell investigation.
Colleagues within the U.S. Embassy in London; McNeil consults Schroeder-Fawcett for information on CBP travel records.
Implied by the investigation context; the MLAT request seeks information on both individuals' travel.
Connection inferred from McNeil's concern that UK authorities might perceive the investigation as targeting Prince Andrew.

events.title: CBP Data Inquiry
events.description: Jennifer Schroeder-Fawcett provides John McNeil with detailed information on APIS (Advance Passenger Information System) data fields available from CBP, including for private aircraft arrivals.

events.title: MLAT Drafting and Strategic Debate
events.description: John McNeil advises Lara that including a request for Epstein and Maxwell's border crossing records in the MLAT could cause UK authorities to hesitate, fearing the request is indirectly targeting Prince Andrew.

events.title: MLAT Finalization
events.description: John McNeil receives a signed version of the MLAT request and indicates he will send it to the UK Central Authority (UKCA).

locations: United States Embassy, 33 Nine Elms Lane, London SW11 7US, United Kingdom
keyFacts: DOJ officials were preparing an MLAT request to the UK in August 2021 as part of the Ghislaine Maxwell investigation (case 182-73090).

A key strategic concern was whether to request Jeffrey Epstein's and Ghislaine Maxwell's border crossing records, due to fears it would make UK authorities 'pause' and think the U.S. was seeking information on Prince Andrew.
U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) retains flight manifest information 'for a very long period,' but Passenger Name Record (PNR) data is destroyed after 5 years.
The email chain reveals internal DOJ coordination between prosecutors in New York and law enforcement attachés in London to gather international evidence.
The correspondence shows sensitivity within the U.S. government about the political dimensions of the investigation, specifically its potential connection to British royalty.
